comments.Question: 84. Comments on job satisfaction
Comments: It's a great place to work, and I would recommend it to others.

I stand with the ideals and values of the Co-Op and that is something that is important for me to feel comfortable in a workplace. That makes me grateful for my job snd proud of the work I do for the people in the community.

Given the overall difficulties the Union has faced with our General Manager, and the general lack of clear communication regarding the direction of the coop to the floor workers (whom feel constantly overworked and are currently facing labor cuts and hiring pauses), I have a lot of difficulty giving an overall positive review of my time working here. Although it is marginally better than other places that I have worked, we can do much better. My disappointment comes from what feels like a constant downward spiral of difficulties that seem to be shouldered only by the lowest paid and hardest working individuals at the store.
I do love it here! but we have some major system issues that need to be ironed out, that will push us to be a super competitive work environment.

I feel fortunate to work at the Coop, a place that shares many of my values and works to build each other and our community up. We've made improvements on communication and operations over the past year and I'm really proud to be a part of that. I appreciate the relationships that I've built with the people that I work with and know that we work with each other with the best intentions. I feel satisfied and happy to come to work each day!
I love working for the Co-op!! What an honor and privilege to be its steward.
While our Co-op is great to work for the pay is not enough to live off of making it a difficult place to work long term or career wise.
It‚Äôs really hard work, for not a lot of money. I enjoy the work I do, and the people I work with, but it takes a lot out of you in the long run.

I know we can be better and always improve - I think we have the right path in mind, the right people, and a dedication to staying true to ourselves regarding diversity, inclusion, community, and communication that is the direct opposite of what the general state of the news and politics is right now. We are incredibly strong in refusing to kowtow to attempts at policies of hatred, bigotry, judgment, and otherwise from our country's top leaders today.
I enjoy the mission and goal of the Co-op all together.

The potential for upward movement to a tech positions does not seem to exist, whether that just be a quirk of the weird size of the business as a whole, or if that room could be carved out in the future with potential consolidation of other marketing roles has yet to be seen. When the marketing team is larger than the produce team, it becomes difficult to see their continued impact on the profits as a whole given the occasional focus on broad outreach, where many people seeing advertisement for the store on platforms like Instagram and Facebook may not be remotely close to the co-op to come in and have an experience with us.

I do like working at a place that our community values so much. I appreciate our repeat customers and the generations of coop shoppers who make a choice to go out of their way to shop regularly at the coop.
I like my job, but it could be better and I do hope it improves.
As a retiree, I am thrilled to be working part-time for the Lexington Co-op.  I repsect management, my departmental colleagues, and, our memeber customers.
I feel good about the work I do here, and the skills I have learned.
I love my job and am proud to work at the Co-Op. I plan on working here for a long time.
im satified with my job but i can offer more to the CoOp with my knowledge and experience
Co-op is my first job, and it has been a pretty nice environment to work at for the last couple years.
Some departments in the Co-op provide a more pleasant work environment than others.

Considering the communication aspect can be worked on when someone goes home or some things have been changed, the coop is a good place to work. I like what I do but I feel like there is a lot of work left to be done. There are also people who don‚Äôt do as much work as others and don‚Äôt get reprimanded for that and it makes me upset. The sole foundation to having a kitchen running effectively is communication and being able to uplift your coworkers. For example, not doing something on your list purposely just because you ‚Äúdon‚Äôt feel like doing it‚Äù. It makes more work for other people and themselves as well.

i'm proud of what the union fights for at this job. i dont have faith our ceo is making good decisions. i thought the coop would have good values and morals but over time i've learned that the most important thing here is profit. the customers feel it too, the coop puts up a facade of diversity and inclusion for a profit.
I enjoy working at the co-op, but the pay makes it difficult to even consider staying employed long-term, as I am unable to pay my bills with the current salary.
I do feel satisfied here. This is only my 3rd job but this is certainty better than the other 2. I do like the co-ops mission and everything that is accomplished here. I'm happy to be part of it.
The co-op is hands down the best place i've ever worked and I truly believe we are one of the best employers in WNY

I think for people at front end it is sometimes hard to be happy to go into work since we sometimes are never able to get away from the register and do something different for a change. Constantly standing and talking to the same customers every day becomes a bore and makes the days seem like they are just flying away. There is nothing new to bring up when people ask about work and it is just not that interesting to come in anymore. It can definitely make you feel burnt out and may make you want to explore different options. I think it is nice when we have those days where we can help out in different departments or just get time to walk away and do some tasks. I can bring your mood up and get the blood flowing back in your bodies again. It really takes a toll on your body when you are stuck at one area for 8.5hrs every shift and makes you quite unenthusiastic.
This is a great place to work!

Overall.response:
The survey reveals a moderately negative overall sentiment (-0.063). While many employees express genuine appreciation for the co-op's mission, values, and a generally welcoming workplace culture, these positives are significantly overshadowed by systemic issues across various operational areas.

A strong undercurrent of dissatisfaction centers on compensation and benefits, with numerous employees struggling to afford a livable wage, citing unaffordable health insurance and inadequate pay that doesn't keep pace with the cost of living. Furthermore, there are widespread concerns regarding internal inconsistencies, particularly in management practices, communication flow, and training/development. Many feel their voices are not heard, decisions are made without their input, and there's a perceived shift towards a more corporate rather than cooperative identity, undermining the democratic principles employees value. Trust in HR and overall management transparency, especially concerning financial details and accountability, appears to be a major challenge, leading to a sense of frustration and disempowerment among staff.

Highlights: Many employees praise the co-op for fostering a welcoming, inclusive, and friendly environment, valuing diversity, and aligning with their personal values, setting a great example for the community.

A significant number of comments express dissatisfaction with the co-op's democratic processes, citing a lack of employee voice in operations, inconsistent information sharing from management, and decisions being made without feedback.

There's a recurring sentiment that the co-op feels increasingly corporate, departing from its original values, with specific mentions of reduced member participation (e.g., volunteering) and influence from larger entities like NCG.
Many comments reveal a lack of uniformity in disciplinary actions, coaching, and policy enforcement across departments and shifts, leading to confusion and frustration among employees.

A notable segment of feedback suggests that management is perceived as prioritizing financial outcomes over employee well-being, with some feeling their voices are unheard and that previous employee advocacy has diminished.

While several employees express satisfaction with their direct managers, praising them as fair, approachable, and supportive, upper management faces criticism for transparency issues, especially regarding critical incidents (e.g., bed bugs) and perceived biases in hiring practices.

Despite some perceived improvements, many employees report a significant disconnect in communication, with crucial information not trickling down to floor staff, and employees feeling consistently left out of decisions or opportunities to provide meaningful input.

Specific incidents, such as unannounced shift changes, uncommunicated benefit information, or critical health/safety issues (like bed bugs in Q15), highlight a failure to provide timely, clear, and relevant communication, leading to frustration and financial hardship for employees.

Communication is often fragmented across departments, with specific concerns about inter-store and inter-departmental information sharing. Additionally, the proliferation of multiple communication platforms (Paylocity, Basecamp, Teams) creates an overwhelming and inefficient experience for employees.

A significant concern is raised about the lack of true "Open Book Management," with employees questioning the completeness of financial reporting, especially regarding senior management salaries, legal fees, and the allocation of funds versus retail floor investment.

Huddles are praised by many as an effective tool for engaged team members to stay informed and feel included, aiding in their understanding of co-op performance and customer interactions. However, accessibility for specific shifts (e.g., overnight staff) and the perception of huddles as a "waste of time" for less engaged employees are noted.

Some employees feel that the amount of information shared in huddles and general communications has decreased over time, leading to more information being "siloed" and a growing distrust in management's commitment to full transparency.

A dominant theme is the inadequacy of current pay rates, with many employees reporting difficulty affording basic necessities like food and rent, often needing second jobs, which is amplified by rising inflation and the high cost of shopping at the co-op itself.

Health insurance is consistently highlighted as "extremely overpriced" and largely unaffordable, especially for those living paycheck-to-paycheck or part-time employees who desire access, with some experiencing personal negative impacts due to poorly communicated changes.

While some acknowledge the union's role in securing competitive benefits and guaranteed raises, there's also dissatisfaction with the union-structured pay, with calls for merit-based raises and concerns that long-term raises do not keep pace with the cost of living or workload.

There are widespread concerns about a lack of standardized systems, recipes, and communication between the Elmwood and Hertel stores, particularly in departments like PFD, leading to operational inefficiencies and product quality discrepancies.

Multiple comments highlight safety issues, including an unsafe parking lot, back room clutter and overflow making movement difficult, and dirty, claustrophobic employee areas, contrasting sharply with clean customer spaces.

Employees point to staffing shortages, frequently broken equipment, outdated technology, and a management culture that is slow to implement necessary changes or incorporate worker feedback as major impediments to efficient operations and productivity.

Many employees highlight issues with accountability for mistakes and quality, inconsistent application of standards, and a lack of clear expectations or defined goals from leadership. This leads to preference-driven workflows and unaddressed performance issues.

There's a strong sentiment of being overburdened, with consistently heavy workloads and unrealistic expectations, especially for departments dealing with multiple initiatives or limited space. This contributes to employee exhaustion, lack of motivation, and high turnover (e.g., overnight staff).

While many praise their direct managers and departmental colleagues for hard work, camaraderie, and team cohesion, there are also reports of favoritism, unequal workload distribution, some employees exhibiting inappropriate behavior, and insufficient communication about departmental goals or changes.

A large number of comments express a profound lack of trust in HR's ability to handle sensitive issues confidentially, fairly, or effectively. Many feel dismissed, misunderstood, or that their issues are made worse, leading some to prefer confiding in direct managers.

Employees report that HR can be slow-moving, difficult to reach, and has communicated poorly around critical events (e.g., health insurance sign-ups). There's also a perception of inconsistent policy application and an outdated, unclear employee handbook.

Direct claims of discrimination within the workplace and "sloppy" handling of injustices from shoppers towards employees are deeply concerning, severely impacting trust in HR's role in ensuring a fair and safe environment.

There is overwhelming feedback indicating a severe deficiency in training, described as "little to no training," "rushed," "incomplete," "inconsistent," and largely peer-led by often untrained staff, leading to employees lacking vital skills, making mistakes, and having unclear job expectations.

Many employees report a significant lack of pathways for career advancement, with development opportunities removed, denied promotions, vague job descriptions, and a perception that growth is "impossible" unless tied directly to profit motives.

Concerns are raised about the effectiveness of existing training tools not being utilized, outdated policies, and the inadequacy of current diversity training. The overall sentiment suggests a fundamental failure in preparing and supporting employees for their roles and future growth.

While many employees express strong positive sentiment towards specific direct managers, praising their fairness, support, approachability, and clarity, there's also significant criticism of others for fostering an unwelcoming environment, favoritism, and inaccessibility.

A recurring issue is the lack of consistent, timely, and constructive feedback from supervisors. Employees report feeling unobserved, evaluated based on second-hand reports, and a general lack of accountability for team members, which contributes to distrust and a sense of drifting without guidance.

Some comments question the overall value of supervisors, feeling more work is pushed onto employees. Specific instances of micromanagement, unprofessional conduct (e.g., public confrontations, sharing inappropriate personal details), and managers who listen but don't "hear" or act on concerns, severely undermine trust and respect.

Many employees express deep satisfaction, pride, and comfort in working for the co-op due to its mission, values (diversity, inclusion), and the positive relationships with colleagues. However, this positive sentiment often clashes with practical concerns like insufficient pay, workload issues, and a perceived shift towards corporate priorities over co-op principles.

A critical barrier to sustained job satisfaction is the struggle for a livable wage, with employees unable to afford basic living expenses or even shop at the co-op itself. This makes the co-op a difficult place for long-term careers despite enjoyment of the work and environment.

Beyond pay, issues like front-end burnout from repetitive tasks, limited opportunities for career advancement (especially in tech or other non-management roles), and feelings of being underutilized, negatively impact enthusiasm and long-term engagement.
